snippet: “The 39 Steps,” the Hitchcock thriller about spies and murder, is at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick.
abstract: Anita Gates reviews play The 39 Steps, adapted by Patrick Barlow from the movie by Alfred Hitchcock, at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick; play is directed by Mark Shanahan and stars Howard McGillin (Metropolitan/New Jersey). Photos (M)s
lead_paragraph: A handsome man accused of murder is running for his life on the roof of a speeding train at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick. Actually, he is pretend-running across some luggage lying on a mostly bare stage, but the audience buys the illusion with a smile. ''The 39 Steps'' was originally a big, serious, classic 1935 Alfred Hitchcock movie about spies between the wars, dashing heroes and classy dames. There was gorgeous black-and-white Scottish and English scenery, and that tingling, suspenseful finale at the London Palladium (nice set by Yoshi Tanokura).

headline.main: Revisiting A Thriller, Revised As a Farce
